answers.text: a) The number of sales of a brand
b) The legal status of a brand
c) The brand-related information stored in memory
d) The global availability of a brand

content: 2. What are the two main components of 'Brand Knowledge'?

answers.text: a) Price and quality
b) Market share and advertising
c) Brand awareness and brand image
d) Logo and design
a) Recognition of the brand when seeing it
b) Retrieval of the brand from memory without a cue
c) Removal of a product from the market
d) Increase in market share
a) Retrieving a brand from memory without any cue
b) Recognizing a brand when seeing a brand element
c) Rejecting a brand from the evoked set
d) Emotional attachment to a brand

content: 5. According to the lecture, which of the following is NOT a dimension of strong brand associations?

answers.text: a) Strength
b) Uniqueness
c) Visibility
d) Favorability

content: 6. What does the 'Evoked Set' describe in the purchase decision process?

answers.text: a) All brands available in the market
b) The brands considered by the consumer for purchase
c) Brands rejected by the consumer
d) Brands unknown to the consumer

content: 7. According to the lecture, how can brand associations be built?

answers.text: a) Only through TV advertising
b) Only through product testing
c) Through every potential brand experience
d) Only through social media

content: 8. According to the lecture, what are 'Brand Attributes'?

answers.text: a) The emotional benefits of the brand
b) The descriptive features of a product
c) Brand recognition
d) Brand loyalty of the target group

content: 9. According to the lecture, what is one goal of the brand image?

answers.text: a) Maximizing the number of brand elements
b) Creating associations that are strong, favorable, and unique
c) Collecting as many associations as possible
d) Aligning brand personality with competitors

content: 10. What is a Point of Parity (PoP) according to the lecture?

answers.text: a) A unique association that only one brand has
b) A shared association with competitor brands
c) A weak association of low importance
d) An internal brand promise

content: 11. What is a Point of Difference (PoD) according to the lecture?

answers.text: a) A functional feature without relevance
b) An association shared with competitors
c) A highly rated, unique brand association
d) A generic product description

content: 12. What does 'Brand Identity' mean according to the lecture?

answers.text: a) The brand image held by consumers
b) The functional attributes of a product
c) The brand associations intended by the company
d) The brand's market awareness

content: 13. What characteristics should a good Point of Difference have according to the lecture?

answers.text: a) It must be easy to imitate
b) It must be cheap to implement internally
c) It should be desirable, deliverable, and differentiating
d) It should already be used by competitors

content: 14. What does an 'associative network' describe in the context of brand knowledge?

answers.text: a) A network of a brand's partner companies
b) A set of interconnected information in long-term memory
c) The supply chain of a brand
d) Internal knowledge management

content: 15. According to Kotler & Keller, what is the goal of 'Brand Positioning'?

answers.text: a) To position the brand as broadly as possible
b) To achieve a neutral positioning
c) To anchor the brand distinctively in the minds of the target group
d) To maximize market share
